title: Why developers killing old-school champions and playstyle ?
body:
Arguably seasons 3 - 5 were the best. Mages were mages and were playable, adc were adc and were playable. There were also a small number of assassins who kept meta at bay. 

Everything started to go downhill when RIOT decided to shift their attention primarily to E-Sports. More speed, more action and interaction made big number of old-school champs and meta unplayable, champs and meta which made this game so popular in the first place. 

Same happen with StarCraft. Original SC:BW game was so fun for casuals that it naturally became E-Sports. SC2  was primarily made for E-Sports in mind and therefore it never reached expectations despite it's early hype. Unfortunately, LOL blinded by its early success now walks the same path.  Players are  leaving this game. In fact, Internet traffic for LOL went down to 30% of what it was back in  2015. LOL still speaks about big number of "unique players", while in fact everybody have at least 2 - 3 alternative accounts and if you tried to level new account you noticed that most of them are smurfs too.  There is a reason why LOL introduced new MISSION: "Teach a Friend" - because there aren't enough new players to play this game.

replies.body: Old school champions typically had kits that were extremely simply and prone to being highly volatile with the slightest changes. They either became highly oppressive, or obsoletes, which is why kits were updated to have more complexity so that the champions didn't exist at one extreme or another.

> [{quoted}](name=Oleandervine,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=lA7zcjTs,comment-id=0001,timestamp=2018-08-09T13:46:33.281+0000)
>
> Old school champions typically had kits that were extremely simply and prone to being highly volatile with the slightest changes. They either became highly oppressive, or obsoletes, which is why kits were updated to have more complexity so that the champions didn't exist at one extreme or another.

And game was fun back then even it was broken in some areas. Developers didn't care that much about 0.1% players base who represented E-Sports either. There were 3 bans for each team to veto broken champs.

Sure, the developer views have changed, but the game is still fun in most scenarios, and the bans _only recently_ got increased to 10 after overwhelming player requests for it, and it wasn't just from eSports, it was casuals too, and everyone in between.

yeah it also just made sense as 3 bans since the beginning, but now there were triple the champions since the original. Also now everyone gets to ban 1 champ so no one can be like OH YOU NO BAN "insert random champ here"

I also liked the early seasons. Everything was tankier, no 1 shot bullshit like you get now. Even assassins didn't get to 1 shot ADC, because you'd see an ADC typically have a GA or Banshee's. Tanks were actually tanky but couldn't nuke anyone late game, yet you couldn't totally ignore Amumu because he'd **eventually** cry your team to death. Eventually.  That was fair.  Assassins had to play around the tanks, just burst through them with armor pen+lethality like they do now but at least they didn't instant explode because they'd build a little defense as well. Everything was fine then, until damage fking creep.
There was a lot of 1 shot in the early seasons. But It was preventable with 1 defensive item, and it wasn't hyper mobile.

Exactly because people actually built defense. I used to DFG-QE on kassandin and nobody survived it, until higher elo where they started getting BV for me. 

Now, damage is so high, you wouldn't survive the 1 shots even with 2 defense items. So what's the point? Just build more damage and hope to out-nuke the enemy,
